Tuckasegee river, at the mouth of Deep creek, near Bryson City, in Swain county, N. C.
Uni&okina;haluna—see Ahalu&okina;na.
Unika&okina;wa—the “Town-house dance,” so-called because danced inside the town-house.
Une&okina;ga-dihi&okina;—“White-man-killer”; from une&okina;ga, “white,” for yun&okina;wune&okina;ga, “white person,” and dihi&okina;, a noun suffix denoting “killer,” “he kills them” (habitually). A Cherokee chief, whose name appears on the documents about 1790.
ungida&okina;—“thy two elder brothers” (male speaking).
ungini&okina;li—“my elder brother.”
ungini&okina;si (plural, tsungini&okina;si)—“my daughter's child.”
u&okina;niskwetu&okina;gi—“they wear a hat,” ulskwe&okina;tawa&okina;, hat from uska&okina;, head. The May apple (Podophyllum).
unistilun&okina;isti—“they stick on along their whole length”; the generic name for “stickers” and burrs, including the Spanish needle, cockle burr, jimson weed, etc.
uni&okina;tsi—her mother; agitsi&okina;, my mother.
Uniya&okina;hitun&okina;yi—“where they shot it,” from tsiya&okina;ihu&okina;. “I shot,” and yi, locative. A place on Tuckasegee river a short distance above Bryson City, in Swain county, N. C.
Unli&okina;ta—“(He is) long-winded,” an archaic form for the regular word, gunli&okina;ta; an old masculine name. A chief about the year 1790, known to the whites as “The Breath.”
Untoola—see Dihiyun&okina;dula&okina;.
Unta&okina;kiyasti&okina;yi—“Where they race,” from takiya&okina;ta, a race, and yi, locative; locally corrupted to Tahkeyostee. The district on the French Broad river, around Asheville, in Buncombe county, N. C. The town itself is known to the Cherokee as Kasdu&okina;yi,
“Ashes place,” (from kasdu, ashes, and yi, locative), which is intended as a translation of its proper name.
Un&okina;tiguhi&okina;—“Pot in water,” from or unti&okina;ya, pot, and guli&okina;, “it is in the water” (or other liquid, habitually). The Suck, a dangerous rapid in Tennessee river, at the entrance of Suck creek, about eight miles below Chattanooga, Tenn.
Untlasgasti&okina;yi—“Where they scratched”; a place at the head of Hyatt's creek of Valley river, in Cherokee county, N. C.
Untoola—see Dihyun&okina;dula&okina;.
Untsaili&okina; (also Etsaiyi&okina;, or Tsaiyi&okina;, the first syllable being almost silent)—“Brass.”
unwada&okina;li—store-house, provision house.
Unwada-tsu&okina;gilasun&okina;—“Where the storehouse (unwada&okina;li) was taken off.” Either Black Rock or Jones' Knob, northeast of Webster, on the east line of Jackson county, N. C.
unun&okina;ti—milk.
usdi&okina;ga (abbreviated usdi&okina;)—small; plural tsunsdi&okina;ga, tsundi&okina;.
usga&okina;se&okina;ti&okina;yu—very dangerous, very terrible; intensive of usga&okina;se&okina;ti.
Uskwale&okina;na—“Big-Head,” from uska&okina;, head; a masculine name, perhaps the original of the “Bull-head,” given by Haywood as the name of a former noted Cherokee warrior.
Uskwa&okina;li-gu&okina;ta—“His stomach hangs down,” from uskwa&okina;li, his stomach, and gu&okina;ta, “it hangs down.” A prominent chief of the Revolutionary period, known to the whites as Hanging-maw.
U&okina;stana&okina;li (from U&okina;stanala&okina;hi or uni&okina;stana&okina;la (a plural form), denoting a natural barrier of rocks
(plural) across a stream)—a name occurring in several places in the old Cherokee country, and variously spelled Eastinaulee, Eastinora, Estanaula, Eustenaree, Istanare, Oostanaula, Oostinawley, Ustenary, etc.
u&okina;stuti—see utsu&okina;gi.
Ustu&okina;tli—a traditional dangerous serpent. The name signifies having something on the calf of the leg or on the heel, from ustutun&okina;i “(his) calf of the leg (attached).” It is applied also to the Southern hoop-snake.
Usunhi&okina;yi—the “Darkening land,” “where it is always getting dark,” as at twilight. The name used for the west in the myths and the sacred formulas; the common word is wude&okina;ligun&okina;yi, “there where it (the sun) goes down.”
u&okina;tanu—great, fully developed. Cf. e&okina;gwa.
utawa&okina;hilu—“hand breadth,” from uwa&okina;yi, hand. A figurative term used in the myths and sacred formulas.
U&okina;tawagun&okina;ta—“Bald place.” A high bald peak in the Great Smoky range on the Tenn.-N. C. line, northeast from Big Pigeon river.
U&okina;tlun&okina;ta—“He (or she) has it sharp,” i. e., has some sharp part or organ; it might be used of a tooth, a finger-nail, or some other attached part of the body.
U&okina;tluntun&okina;yi—“U&okina;tlun&okina;ta place”; see U&okina;tlun&okina;ta. A place on Little Tennessee river, nearly off Citico creek, in Blount county, Tenn.
U&okina;tsala—“Lichen”; another form of utsale&okina;ta. A Cherokee chief of Removal period in 1838.
utsale&okina;ta—lichen, literally “pot scrapings,” from a fancied resemblance.
utsa&okina;nati&okina;—rattlesnake; the name is of doubtful etymology, but is said to refer to the rattle.
Utsa&okina;nati&okina;yi—“Rattlesnake place.” Rattlesnake springs, about two miles south from Charlestown, Bradley county, Tenn.
utset&okina;sti—“he grins” (habitually). See si&okina;kwa utset&okina;sti.
utsi&okina;—her (his) mother; etsi&okina;, agitsi&okina;, my mother.
Utsi&okina;dsata&okina;—“Corn-tassel,” “Thistle-head,” etc. It is used as a masculine name, and was probably the Cherokee name of the chief of Revolutionary times, known as “Old Tassel.”
utsu&okina;gi—the tufted titmouse (Parus bicolor); also called u&okina;stuti&okina;, “topnot, or tip,” on account of its crest.
u&okina;tsuti&okina;—fish. Also, many.
Uwaga&okina;hi (commonly written Ocoee)—“Apricot place,” from uwa&okina;ga, the “apricot vines,” or “maypop,” (Passiflora incarnata), and hi, locative. A former important settlement on Ocowe river, near its junction with Hiwassee, about the present Benton, in Polk county, Tenn.
uwa&okina;yi—hand, paw, generally used with the possessive suffix, as uwaye&okina;ni, “his hand.”
uwe&okina;la—liver.
uwe&okina;nahi—rich; used also as a personal name.
Uw&okina;tsun&okina;ta—“Bouncer” (habitual); from k&okina;tsi, “it is bouncing.” A traditional serpent described as moving by jerks like a measuring worm, to which also the name is applied.
Uyahye&okina;—a high peak in the Great Smoky range, probably on the line between Swain county, N. C., and Sevier county, Tenn.
Uy&okina;gila&okina;gi—abbreviated from Tsuyu&okina;gila&okina;gi, “where there are dams,” i. e., beaver dams; from gu&okina;gilu&okina;unsku&okina;, “he is damming it.” 1. A former settlement on
Oothcaloga (Ougillogy) creek of Oostanaula river, near the present Calhoun, in Gordon county, Ga.; 2. Beaverdam creek, west of Clarksville, in Habbersham county, Ga.
Valleytown—see Gu&okina;nahitun&okina;yi.
Vengeance creek—see Gansa&okina;ti&okina;yi.
Wachesa—see Watsi&okina;su.
wadan&okina;—thanks!
wa&okina;di—paint, especially red paint.
wa&okina;dige-aska&okina;li—“his head (is) brown,” i. e., “brown-head”; from wadige&okina;i, brown, brown-red, and aska&okina;li, head; the copperhead snake.
Wadi&okina;yahi—a feminine name of doubtful etymology. An expert basket-making woman among the East Cherokee, who died in 1895. She was known to the whites as Mrs. Bushyhead.
Wafford—see Tsuskwanun&okina;ta.
Wa&okina;ginsi—the name of an eddy at the junction of Little Tennessee and the main Tennessee rivers at Lenoir, in London county, Tenn. The town is now known to the Cherokee by the same name, of which the meaning is lost.
waguli&okina;—whippoorwill; the name is an onomatope; the Delaware name is wekolis.
Wahnenauhi—see Wani&okina;nahi.
wa&okina;huhu&okina;—the screech-owl.
wa&okina;ka—cow; from the Spanish vaca, as is also the Creek waga and the Arapaho wakuch.
wala&okina;si—the common green frog.
Walasi&okina;yi—“Frog place.” 1. A former settlement, known to the whites as Frogtown, upon the creek of the same name, north of Dahlonega, in Lumpkin
county, Ga. 2. Le Conte and Bullhead Mountains in the Great Smoky range on the N. C.-Tenn. line, together with the ridge extending into Sevier county, Tenn., between the Middle and West forks of Little Pigeon river.
walas&okina;-unul&okina;sti—“it fights frogs,” from wala&okina;si, frog, and unul&okina;sti, “it fights” (habitually); gu&okina;lihu&okina;, “I am fighting.” The Prosartes lanuginosa plant.
Walas&okina;-unulstiyi&okina;—“Place of the plant,” walas&okina;-unul&okina;sti, commonly known to the whites as Fightingtown, from a translation of the latter part of a name; a former settlement on Fighting creek, near Morgantown, in Fannin county, Ga.
Walini&okina;—a feminine name, compounded from Wali, another form of Kwali, “Polly,” with a suffix added for euphony.
Wane&okina;-asun&okina;tlunyi—“Hickory footlog place,” from wane&okina;i, hickory, asun-tlun&okina;i (q. v.), footlog, bridge, and yi, locative. A former settlement, known to the whites as Hickory-log, on Etowah river, a short distance above Canton, in Cherokee county, Ga.
Wani&okina;nahi&okina;—a feminine name of uncertain etymology; the Wahnenauhi of the Wahnenauhi manuscript.
Washington—see Wa&okina;situ&okina;na.
Wa&okina;si—the Cherokee form for Moses.
Wa&okina;situ&okina;na, Wa&okina;suntu&okina;na (different dialect forms)—a Cherokee known to the whites as Washington, the sole survivor of a Removal tragedy. The name denotes a hollow log (or other cylindrical object) lying on the ground at a distance; the root of the word is asi&okina;ta, log, and the w prefix indicates distance.
Wa&okina;sulu&okina;—a large red-brown moth which flies about blossoming tobacco in the evening.
Wata&okina;gi (commonly written Watauga, also Wataga, Wattoogee, Whatoga, etc.)—a name occurring in two or more towns in the old Cherokee country; one was an important settlement on Watauga creek of Little Tennessee river, a few miles below Franklin, in Macon county, N. C.; another was traditionally located at Watauga Old Fields, about the present Elizabethton on Wateuga river, in Carter county, Tenn. The meaning is lost.
Watau&okina;ga—see Wata&okina;gi.
Watsi&okina;sa—a prominent old Cherokee, known to the whites as Wachesa, a name which cannot be translated, who formerly lived on Beaverdam creek of Hiwassee river, below Murphy, in Cherokee county, N. C. From the fact that the Unicoi turnpike passed near his place, it was locally known as Wachesa trail.
wa&okina;ya—wolf; an onomatope, an imitation of the animal's howl; cf. the Creek name, yaha.
Wa&okina;ya&okina;hi—“Wolf place,” i. e., place of the Wolf clan; the form Ani&okina;Wa&okina;ya&okina;hi is not used. Wolftown settlement on upper Soco creek, on the East Cherokee reservation, in Jackson county, N. C.
Waya Gap—see A&okina;tahi&okina;ta.
Wayeh—see Wayi.
Wayi—“Pigeon”; the modern Cherokee name for Big Pigeon river, in western N. C.; probably a translation of the English name. It appears also as Wayeh.
Welch, Lloyd—see Da&okina;si&okina;giya&okina;gi.
wesa—cat.
White-path—see Nunna&okina;hi-tsune&okina;ga.
Willstown—a former important settlement, so-called from the half-breed chief known to the whites as Red-headed Will, on Will's creek below Fort
Payne, in Dekalb county, Ala. The settlement was frequently called from him Wili&okina;yi, “Will's place,” but this was not the proper local name.
Wilsini&okina;—The Cherokee name for H. W. Spray, agent and superintendent for the East Cherokee reservation; an adaptation of his middle name, Wilson.
Wil-usdi&okina;—“Little Will,” from Wili&okina;, Will and usdi&okina;ga or usdi&okina;, little. The Cherokee name for Colonel W. H. Thomas, for many years the recognized chief of the eastern band.
Wissactaw—see gahawi&okina;stia.
Wolftown—see Wa&okina;ya&okina;hi.
Wootassite—see Outacity.
Wrosetasatow—see Outacity.
Wude&okina;ligun&okina;yi—the west; literally “there where it (the sun) goes down,” (w prefixed implies distance, yi, locative). See also Usunhi&okina;yi and wusuhihun&okina;yi.
Wuliga&okina;natutun—excelling all others, either good or bad; it may be used as equivalent to wastun, “beyond the limit.”
wusuhihun&okina;yi—“there where they stay over night,” i. e., “the west.” An archaic term used by the narrator of the story of Untsaiyi&okina;.
Xuala—see Ani-Suwa&okina;li.
ya—a suffix denoting principal or real, as tsiskwa&okina;ya, “principal bird,” the sparrow; Ani&okina;-Yunwiya&okina;, “principal or real people,” Indians.
Yahula&okina;li—“Yahu&okina;la place,” from Yuhu&okina;la, a Cherokee trader said to have been taken by the spirit people; Yahu&okina;la, seems to be from the Creek yoho&okina;lo, a name having reference to the song (yoholo), used in the “black drink” ceremony of the Creeks; thus
a&okina;si-yoho&okina;lo, corrupted into Osceola, signified “the black drink song”; it may, however, be a true Cherokee word, yahu&okina;lu or yahu&okina;li, the name for a variety of hickory, also for the “doodle-bug”; Unyahu&okina;la is a feminine name, but cannot be translated. Yahoola creek, near Dahlonega, in Lumpkin county, Ga.
Yala&okina;gi—Alarka creek of Little Tennessee river, above the junction of Tuckasegee, in Swain county, N. C.; the meaning of the name is lost.
yandaska&okina;ga—a faultfinder.
Yan-e&okina;gwa—“Big-Bear,” from yanu, bear, and egwa, great, large. A prominent chief about the year 1800; the name occurs in treaties as Yonah, Yohanaqua and Yonahequah.
ya&okina;nu—bear.
Ya&okina;nu-dinehun&okina;yi—“where the bears live,” from yanu, bear, dinehu&okina;, “they dwell” (e&okina;hu, “I dwell, I live”) and yi, locative. A place on Oconaluftee river, a short distance above the junction with Tuckasegee, in Swain county, N. C.
Yanugun&okina;ski—“the bear drowns him” (habitually), from yanu, bear, and tsigun&okina;iska&okina;, “I am drowning him.” A noted East Cherokee chief, known to the whites as Yonaguska or Drowning-bear.
yan&okina;-utse&okina;stu—“The bear lies on it”; the shield fern (Aspidium).
Ya&okina;nu-u&okina;natawasti&okina;yi—“where the bears wash,” (from yanu, bear, and yi, locative); a former pond in the Great Smoky Mountains, about the head of Raven Fork, in Swain county, N. C.
Yawa&okina;i—“Yawa place”; a place on Yellow creek of Cheowa river, in Graham county, N. C.
Yellow-Hill—see Elawa&okina;diyi.
Yohanaqua—see Yan-e&okina;gwa.
yoho-o!—an unmeaning song refrain.
Yonaguska—see Ya&okina;nugun&okina;ski.
Yonah—1. (mountain) see Gadalu&okina;lu. 2. An abbreviated treaty form for the name of the chief Yana&okina;gwa.
Yonahequah—see Yan-e&okina;gwa.
Ytaua, Ytava—see I&okina;tawa&okina;.
Yu!—an unmeaning song refrain and interjection.
Yuha&okina;li—Euharlee creek, of lower Etowah river, in Bartow county, Ga. The name is said by the Cherokee to be a corruption of Yufala (Eufaula), a well known Creek local name.
yunsu&okina;—buffalo; cf. Creek yena&okina;sa, Choctaw yanash, Hichitee ya&okina;nasi.
Yunsa&okina;i—“Buffalo place”; West Buffalo creek of Cheowa river in Graham county, N. C.; the site of a former Cherokee settlement.
yun&okina;wi—person, man.
Yun&okina;wi Ama&okina;yine&okina;hi—“Water-dwelling people,” from yun&okina;wi, person, and ama&okina;yine&okina;hi, plural of amaye&okina;hi, q. v.; a race of water fairies.
Yun&okina;wi Gunahi&okina;ta—“Long Man”; a formulistic name for the river, personified as a man with his head resting on the mountain and his feet stretching down to the lowlands, who is constantly speaking to those who can understand the message.
Yun&okina;wini&okina;gisgi—“man-eaters,” literally, “They eat people” (habitually), from yun&okina;wi, person, man, and uni, giski, “they eat” (habitually), from tsikiu&okina;, “I am eating”; the Cherokee name for a distant cannibal tribe, possibly the Atakapa or the Tonkawa.
Yun&okina;wi-tsulenun&okina;yi—“where man stood,” originally yun&okina;wi-dikatagun&okina;yi, “where the man stands,” from yun&okina;wi, person, man, tsita&okina;ga, “I am standing,” and yi, locative; Standing Indian, a high bald mountain at the head of Nantahala river, in Macon county, N. C.
Yun&okina;wi Tsunsdi&okina;—“little people,” from yun&okina;wi, person, people, and tsunsdi&okina;ga or tsunsdi, plural of usdi&okina;ga or usdi&okina;, little; the Cherokee fairies.
Yun&okina;wi Usdi&okina;—“little man.” A formulistic name for ginseng, a&okina;tali-guli&okina;, q. v.
Yun&okina;wi-usga&okina;se&okina;ti—“dangerous man, terrible man”; a traditional leader in the westward migration of Cherokee.
Yun&okina;wiya&okina;—“Indian,” literally, “principal or real person,” from yun&okina;wi, person, and ya, a suffix denoting principal or real.
yu&okina;we-yuwehe&okina;—an unmeaning song refrain.
High Falls, Buck Forest, N. C.
“And it bounds full many a fathom
In its final furious fall.”
Melrose Falls, Tryon, N. C.
“Plunges down deep in the gulches
Where the rocks are worn with age.”
